awd_titl_txt: Acquisition of a Laser Flash Apparatus to simultaneously measure thermal diffusivity and heat capacity from 173 to 773 K
awd_abstract_narration:
The flow of heat affects everyday activities such as cooking food, and is important to engineering problems such as manufacturing small cell phones that do not overheat. This award will provide funding for a new laser flash apparatus for determining heat flow. This new instrument will add to the infrastructure needed to advance fundamental issues in Earth and other physical sciences. It will have many practical applications to problems involving heat transfer.

This award funds the acquisition of laser flash apparatus, which will improve the database on heat transport, further understanding of dynamic processes over a wide temperature range, and advance thermal models used to address diverse problems in Earth and planetary science. Problems possible to address include cooling of dust grains in meteorites, crystallization and evolution of plutons, dissipation of friction during plate motions, melting of the core, and deducing the thermal structure and evolution of rocky and ice planetary bodies. These new data will permit addressing the thermal structure and evolution of Solar System objects and exoplanets. Accurate heat flow data also bear on engineering problems, since ceramics and glasses are closely related, and sometimes identical, to the materials being examined.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Title: Acquisition of a Laser Flash Apparatus to simultaneously measure thermal diffusivity and heat capacity from 173 to 773 K

 

Heat flow is everywhere from everything. The flow of heat affects everyday activities such as cooking food, and is important to engineering problems such as manufacturing small cell phones that do not overheat. In loosing heat, objects change and so the loss of heat from Earth’s surface pertains to its evolution. Volcanism exemplifies drastic heat loss, where this hazard impacts society. The physical property that is used to quantify the flow of heat is known as thermal conductivity.  Thermal conductivity (K) consists of two parts, how fast heat moves (D, thermal diffusivity) and how much heat is being moved (C, heat capacity or storativity). Most experimental methods measure K, but these are not accurate for materials which allow certain wavelengths of light to pass through (rocks, glasses: anything other than metals). As a consequence, the physical process of heat flow has been misunderstood. Our previous use of  a high-temperature laser flash apparatus (an LFA467) that accurately measures D, due to this technique centering on the flow of heat with time across a well-defined distance, has led to a new physical model of heat flow that is based how light behaves inside matter.  The 2-centuries old discovery of the equivalence of light and heat was not heretofore used to describe heat conduction. Accurate data are needed at low temperature, where properties change rapidly, to further improve our understanding of the process, and to confidently predict K and D at inaccessible conditions, e.g., deep inside Earth.  To address diverse problems, good data are needed. This grant funded acquisition of a low- to moderate temperature LFA, which will provide the needed data on both D and C, which yield K. A confirmed, predictive model will also be of use to technological applications, since heat flow is ubiquitous. Thus, this new instrument has added to the infrastructure needed to advance fundamental issues in Earth and other physical sciences. It will have many practical applications to problems involving heat transfer, since the new LFA467 is optimal at the condition most commonly encountered, room temperature. The instrument was installed and tested, and we are currently busy calibrating the heat capacity measurements against standards, to achieve the highest accuracy possible in ascertaining thermal conductivity.

Modified by: Anne M Hofmeister
